item.title: Alien abduction (disambiguation)
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

This entry serves as a disambiguation page for the term “Alien abduction.” It directs users to various articles related to the concept.

Film ðŸ”—

This section lists films with “Alien Abduction” in their title.

  • Alien Abduction (2005 film): A science-fiction horror film produced by The Asylum.
  • Alien Abduction (2014 film): A science-fiction horror film directed by Matty Beckerman.
  • Alien Abduction: Incident in Lake County: A 1998 found-footage film directed by Dean Alioto.
  • *“Alien Abductions” (Bullshit! episode): A 2003 episode of Penn & Teller: Bullshit!

Other uses ðŸ”—

This section lists other uses of the term “Alien Abduction.”

  • Alien Abduction: An alternate name for the roller coaster Gravitron.
  • Alien abduction insurance: An insurance policy issued against alien abduction.
  • Alien abduction entities: Beings alleged to secretly abduct people.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to a related film.

  • UFO Abduction (film): A 1989 found footage/thriller film.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_(disambiguation)

item.title: Jason Colavito
item.description:
Jason Colavito ðŸ”—

Jason Colavito, born in 1981, is an American author and independent scholar known for his work debunking fringe theories, particularly those related to ancient history and extraterrestrials. He has written several books on these topics.

Biography ðŸ”—

Colavito graduated summa cum laude from Ithaca College in 2003 with a bachelor’s degree in anthropology and journalism. He attended Auburn High School before that. His work focuses on debunking alternative archaeology. His work has been cited in The Washington Post, The Huffington Post, and on the History Channel.

Bibliography ðŸ”—

Colavito’s writings have appeared in The New Republic, Slate, Esquire Magazine, and Skeptic magazine.

Books (as author):

  • The Cult of Alien Gods: H. P. Lovecraft and Extraterrestrial Pop Culture (2005) explores the influence of H.P. Lovecraft’s Cthulhu Mythos on the works of Erich von DÃ¤niken and Graham Hancock, and its impact on extraterrestrial pop culture.
  • Knowing Fear: Science, Knowledge, and the Development of the Horror Genre (2007) examines the history and science of the horror genre.
  • A Critical Companion to Ancient Aliens Seasons 3 and 4: Unauthorized (2012)
  • Faking History: Essays on Aliens, Atlantis, Monsters, and More (2013)
  • Unearthing the Truth: An Unauthorized Commentary on America Unearthed Season One (2013)
  • Cthulhu in World Mythology (2014)
  • Jason and the Argonauts Through the Ages (2014)
  • The Mound Builder Myth: Fake History and the Hunt for a “Lost White Race” (2020) discusses the myth surrounding mound builders and its connection to ideas of a lost white race.
  • The Legends of the Pyramids (2021)
  • Jimmy: The Secret Life of James Dean (2024)

Books (as editor):

  • A Hideous Bit of Morbidity: An Anthology of Horror Criticism from the Enlightenment to World War I (2009)
  • Unseen Horror: 15 Tales of Invisibility and the Macabre (2011)
  • The Faust Book: And Other Early Stories of Dr. Faustus (2011)
  • Moon Men!: A Lunar Anthology of Proto-Science Fiction, A.D. 200â€“1835 (2012)
  • Theosophy on Ancient Astronauts (2012)
  • Pyramidiots: Outrageous Theories about the Great Pyramid (2012)
  • Foundations of Atlantis, Ancient Astronauts and Other Alternative Pasts: 148 Documents Cited by Writers of Fringe History (2015)

Books (as translator):

  • The Orphic Argonautica (2011)
  • The XipÃ©hux (2012)

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the various sources cited throughout the article, including news articles, academic journals, and websites. These sources provide verification for the information presented about Jason Colavito’s life, work, and publications.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cult_of_Alien_Gods
